{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3247063,"name":"Falon Clark","username":"Tatiman-Dev","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tatiman-dev/{size}/236095_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-30T05:16:45.225Z","cooked":"

Is there a way to display and tweak SparkMax PID controllers like you can with the default WPILIB pidcontroller?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-10-30T05:16:45.225Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":104,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":541.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":443344,"topic_slug":"sparkmax-pidcontroller-shuffleboard-display","display_username":"Falon Clark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57393,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The Kotlin Guy"},"post_url":"/t/sparkmax-pidcontroller-shuffleboard-display/443344/1","custom_user_title":"The Kotlin Guy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3247112,"name":"Oliver | 1986","username":"Oliver_W","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oliver_w/{size}/231411_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-30T12:50:11.392Z","cooked":"

The way that I would do this would be to use a getNumber() method and set this value to a variable to pass in. I’m new to Java this year though so I’m sure that there is a better way to do this.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-10-30T12:50:11.392Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":64.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":443344,"topic_slug":"sparkmax-pidcontroller-shuffleboard-display","display_username":"Oliver | 1986","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/smartdashboard/SmartDashboard.html#getNumber(java.lang.String,double)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SmartDashboard (WPILib API 2023.4.3)","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1986 Driver | MoSim Co-Developer"},"post_url":"/t/sparkmax-pidcontroller-shuffleboard-display/443344/2","custom_user_title":"1986 Driver | MoSim Co-Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3247182,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-30T15:35:37.708Z","cooked":"

You need to write some code here, but it’s possible. I have a C++ example, but not one in Java. One way involves using Shuffleboard, but if you have a preference on the UI side, it would be good to mention this here. It might be best to find a working Java example and go from there, but here’s more on the C++ code…

You can break this into parts – first, you’ll need some code to interact with the Shuffleboard PID widget: https://github.com/Jagwires7443/Scrappy/blob/master/src/main/include/infrastructure/ShuffleboardWidgets.h#L38. The point of this code is to get and set values that are shown in this widget. You also need to instantiate this class: https://github.com/Jagwires7443/Scrappy/blob/master/src/main/cpp/subsystems/DriveSubsystem.cpp#L467.

When the PID constants change, you’ll want to apply the changes to the SPARK MAX controllers you are using with the given set of tuning constants. The code to do this in the C++ project is fairly involved, but provides a clean API for smart motors and totally manages all of the settings: https://github.com/Jagwires7443/Scrappy/blob/master/src/main/include/infrastructure/SparkMax.h. You need to tie together the widget settings and those of the motor controllers, plus have code to run the motors.

We only run this sort of code in test mode, but you could also have a test project for this. We don’t want to mess with these tuning settings once we are running teleop or auto. One thing we do to make tuning PID so much easier to to use ProfiledPID controller and feedforward, as appropriate. As a result, we hardly use the ability to interactively mess with the PID constants.
